                              ---
                              CLand is a Convergence Institute funded by the French government in 2017 to perform in the next decade the research urgently needed on land-management solutions for managing the ecological and energy transitions of the 21st century.

CLand develops new cross-disciplinary research across leading teams in the Paris area in modelling climate change, food and fibre production, biodiversity dynamics, ecosystem functioning and land-use socio-economics. In addition to models, data syntheses will help understand key feedbacks and assess risks and sustainable options for integrated management of land ecosystems.

CLand aims to support the activity of 200 researchers in 12 teams, and to develop a graduate programme across Master and Doctoral schools of the University of Paris Saclay, in partnership with European and international institutes.

                              Title: What if AI could help us better understand plastic pollution?
Description: Rivers are highways for plastic pollution. What if AI could help us track and stop it?

Meet Surfnet: a miniature, highly specialised AI trained on 5,000 labelled images to detect litter stranded on riverbanks. With the help of more than 150 passionate volunteers, we combined computer vision + video tracking to collect robust data in complex environments.

üí° Why does this matter?

‚û°Ô∏è 80% of ocean plastic comes from land-based sources‚Äîrivers being a key entry point. If we don‚Äôt act upstream, we‚Äôll never solve the problem downstream. 

‚û°Ô∏è Plastic Origins maps plastic pollution in European rivers to empower stakeholders with actionable data.

‚û°Ô∏è The best part? The dataset & AI model are open-source, so others can build on our work.

A huge thank you to our volunteers and partners who made this possible! üôå

Title: Blue Up 2024 - Ocean Debate (Full version)
Description: In light of the triple crisis of climate change, biodiversity loss, and pollution facing our planet, the urgency of effective ocean governance cannot be overstated. As an Ocean community, we must seize this critical moment to advocate for representatives who prioritise ocean protection. Our engagement in the electoral process sends a powerful message to future decision-makers, urging them to prioritise the health and well-being of our ocean in their policy making agendas.

Blue Up 2024 is a coalition of European organisations working for a better protected Ocean. We are campaigning to put ocean protection at the heart of the political agenda ahead, during and after the European elections.

By mobilising our networks, amplifying our voices, and advocating for ocean-friendly policies through the Blue Up 2024 campaign we can inform our communities, citizens and networks on the importance of getting their Blue Votes in! 

visit www.oceanvoice.eu

L'effondrement des populations d'insectes est largement document√© par les scientifiques (https://www.inrae.fr/actualites/comment-sauver-colonies-dabeilles#:~:text=Les%20observations%20sont%20formelles%20%3A%20depuis,sont%20en%20voie%20d'extinction.)  du monde entier. Une r√©duction spectaculaire de 95,1% de la biomasse totale s'est¬† en seulement 24 ans, selon une √©tude publi√©e dans Pest Science en 2023 (https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10340-023-01698-2#citeas) . Selon l'Anses (https://www.anses.fr/fr/content/sante-des-abeilles#:~:text=Les%20abeilles%20repr%C3%A9sentent%2090%20%25%20des,est%20constat%C3%A9%20dans%20le%20monde.) , les abeilles repr√©sentent 90% des insectes (https://magazine.hortus-focus.fr/blog/2020/11/19/les-insectes-des-bebetes-passionnantes/)  pollinisateurs, aux c√¥t√©s des bourdons, des papillons ou des mouches.


Et, comme l'√©crit Greenpeace (https://www.greenpeace.org/canada/fr/story-fr/59827/trois-raisons-pour-lesquelles-nous-devons-sauver-les-abeilles/) , le bourdon am√©ricain, une esp√®ce indig√®ne du Canada, est au bord de l‚Äôextinction. Les scientifiques estiment qu‚Äôil a connu un d√©clin stup√©fiant de 99 % au cours des trois derni√®res d√©cennies.


Notre monde, celui habitable par les humains, est menac√©. Ce sont eux qui assurent le transport du pollen et du nectar (https://magazine.hortus-focus.fr/blog/2024/05/19/le-seringat-beaute-et-parfum/)  de 80% des plantes √† fleurs. L'artificialisation des sols, la disparition des haies, l'accroissement des infrastructures de mobilit√© font disparaitre l'habitat des pollinisateurs.

Fortes amplitudes des temp√©ratures, tornades, vents ou pluies violentes malm√®ne les organismes. Que l'on soit abeille, plante ou humain, les √©volutions du climat impactent nos modes de vie et nos sant√©s.
